messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 20, 2019 - March 26, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-03-27T20:17:54Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-03-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-03-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190327-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There was 1 C-type CME (see details below). Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that this CME (starting at 2019-03-20T08:24:00Z) may impact OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow) at around 2019-03-24T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) and missions near Earth at around 2019-03-23T11:11Z (see notifications 20190320-AL-001 and 20190321-AL-001). This CME arrival was detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2019-03-24T20:43Z.  
 
Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-03-21. Solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2019-03-21. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2019-03-20T08:24Z     ~541            C                14/1                 41                          STEREO A                          

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-03-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-04-02T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are no active regions currently visible at the surface of the sun. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-03-28. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (MESSENGER, OSIRIS-REx, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-03-21T22:19:29Z
## Message ID: 20190321-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME(s) with ID(s) 2019-03-20T08:24:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20190320-AL-001). Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Out of 41 ensemble members (see notes section), 40 (97%) indicate impact at NASA missions near Earth. Ensemble simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2019-03-23T02:46Z and 2019-03-24T02:40Z (average arrival 2019-03-23T15:22Z). The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 72% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 2-3 range (below minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2019-03-21_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070/20190320_082400_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2019-03-21_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070/20190320_082400_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2019-03-21_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070/20190320_082400_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2019-03-21_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070/20190320_082400_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2019-03-21_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070/Detailed_results_20190320_082400_ncmes1_sims41_HILOX070.txt
##


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 13, 2019 - March 19, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-03-20T18:29:22Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-03-13T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-03-19T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190320-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2019-03-17T00:00Z-03:00Z. This elevation of geomagnetic activity was associated with a combination of the arrival of a weak coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2019-03-15 and the arrival of a S-type CME around 2019-03-17.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~450 km/s on 2019-03-17.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-03-20T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-03-26T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are currently several small active regions present on the visible solar disk that may have some potential for flares or CMEs.  Recently numbered active region 12736 had some flare activity, the highest being a C4.8 class flare that peaked at 2019-03-20T11:18Z.  A C-type CME was associated with this activity. Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow) around 2019-03-24T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth around 2019-03-23T11:11Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20190320-AL-001).  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (OSIRIS-REx, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-03-20T17:23:00Z
## Message ID: 20190320-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A. 

Start time of the event: 2019-03-20T08:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~541 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 41 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 14/1 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2019-03-20T08:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach OSIRIS-REx at 2019-03-24T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2019-03-23T11:11Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2019-03-20T08:24:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190320_181900_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Osiris_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2019-03-20T08:24:00-CME-001) is associated with the B6.1 flare with ID 2019-03-20T07:05:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2019-03-20T07:14Z and the C4.8 flare with ID 2019-03-20T10:35:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2019-03-20T11:18Z.


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 06, 2019 - March 12, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-03-13T18:16:47Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-03-06T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-03-12T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190313-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. A S-type (<500 km/s) CME started at 2019-03-08T04:17Z as seen from the SOHO LASCO imagery.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic period of 2019-03-12T06:00Z-09:00Z. This slight elevation in geomagnetic activity may be associated with the arrival of the S-type CME described above (see notification 20190309-AL-001).  
 
The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-03-13T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-03-19T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are currently several small active regions present on the visible solar disk that may have some potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-03-15.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-03-09T14:56:25Z
## Message ID: 20190309-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2019-03-08T04:17Z.

Estimated speed: ~340 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 27 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 3/7 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2019-03-08T04:17:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2019-03-11T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-4 (below minor).

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2019-03-08T04:17:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190308_144400_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190308_144400_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190308_144400_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190308_144400_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190308_144400_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190308_144400_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190308_144400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190308_144400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20190308_144400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2019-03-08T04:17:00-CME-001) is associated with the C1.3 flare with ID 2019-03-08T03:07:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2019-03-08T03:18Z.


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 27, 2019 - March 05, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-03-06T21:28:39Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-02-27T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-03-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190306-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-02-28T00:00Z-03:00Z, 2019-02-28T12:00Z-15:00Z and 2019-03-01T03:00Z-06:00Z. This elevation of geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2019-02-27.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2019-03-01.  

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-03-01T15:45Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES are associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20190301-AL-001, 20190301-AL-002, 20190303-AL-001 and 20190305-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-03-06T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-03-12T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are currently several small active regions present on the visible solar disk that may have potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-03-06.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continuing Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-03-05T19:40:36Z
## Message ID: 20190305-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20190301-AL-001, 20190301-AL-002, and 20190303-AL-001. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux exceeded 10^5 pfu at 2019-03-01T15:45Z and has continued to be near or above the threshold. Flux is currently around 70,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by  high speed stream starting at 2019-02-27T11:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-03-01T15:45:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-03-03T16:12:14Z
## Message ID: 20190303-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20190301-AL-001 and 20190301-AL-002. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux exceeded 10^5 pfu at 2019-03-01T15:45Z and has continued to cross the threshold, most recently at approximately 2019-03-03T10:00Z. Flux is currently around 143,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2019-02-27T11:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-03-01T15:45:00-RBE-001.
